Question Text: In a spoofing attack, which of the following parameters are commonly spoofed? (Choose two answers)
Choices:
a. Source IP address
b. MAC address
c. ARP address
d. Routing table
e. Destination IP address
f. ARP table
LLM Explanation: In a spoofing attack, the attacker typically falsifies or 'spoofs' the source IP address and/or the MAC address. By spoofing the source IP, the attacker can hide their true identity and location, making it appear as if the malicious traffic is originating from a different IP address. Similarly, by spoofing the MAC address, the attacker can impersonate a legitimate device on the network. The other choices - ARP address, routing table, destination IP address, and ARP table - are not commonly spoofed parameters in a spoofing attack.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press, 2020)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/what-is-spoofing.html', 'https://www.imperva.com/learn/application-security/spoofing-attack/']

Question Text: AAA servers usually support the protocol TACACS+ and ____________________ to communicate with enterprise resources.
Choices:
a. DHCP
b. ARP
c. RADIUS
d. HTTP
LLM Explanation: RADIUS (Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service) is commonly used alongside TACACS+ as an AAA (Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting) protocol to communicate with enterprise resources. RADIUS provides centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting management for users who connect and use a network service.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, by Wendell Odom', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/identity-services-engine/what-is-radius-authentication.html']

Question Text:
The senior network engineer assigns you a task related to port security. He needs your help to configure the fa0/1 from the SW-examsD to accept frames only from the MAC 0200.1111.2222.
Type the commands that need to be configured on the SW-examsD following the requirements below:
1. configure the FastEthernet0/1 to be an access port
2. enable port security on that interface
3. define the allowed MAC address
Choices:
a. SW-examsD#configure terminal
SW-examsD(config)#interface FastEthernet0/2
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport mode access
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security macaddress 0200.1111.2222
b. SW-examsD#configure terminal
SW-examsD(config)#interface FastEthernet0/1
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport mode access
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security
c. SW-examsD#configure terminal
SW-examsD(config)#interface FastEthernet0/1
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport mode access
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security macaddress 0200.2222.2222
d. SW-examsD#configure terminal
SW-examsD(config)#interface FastEthernet0/1
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport mode access
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security macaddress 0200.1111.2222
LLM Explanation: Option d is the correct set of commands to meet the given requirements. It configures FastEthernet0/1 as an access port, enables port security on that interface, and defines the allowed MAC address as 0200.1111.2222. Option a configures the wrong interface (fa0/2 instead of fa0/1). Option b enables port security but does not define the allowed MAC address. Option c defines the wrong allowed MAC address (0200.2222.2222 instead of 0200.1111.2222).
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 11: Implementing Ethernet Virtual LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst2960/software/release/12-2_55_se/configuration/guide/scg_2960/swtrafc.html']

Question Text: _____________________ attacks typically function by overwhelming or flooding a targeted machine with requests until normal traffic is unable to be processed, resulting in denial- of-service to additional users.
Choices:
a. Spoofing
b. Phishing
c. DoS
d. SQL injection
LLM Explanation: Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks aim to make a machine or network resource unavailable to its intended users by temporarily or indefinitely disrupting services of a host connected to the Internet. This is typically accomplished by flooding the targeted machine or resource with superfluous requests in an attempt to overload systems and prevent some or all legitimate requests from being fulfilled.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, Chapter 8: Network Security Fundamentals by Wendell Odom', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/what-is-a-ddos-attack.html']

Question Text: A _________________ is malicious software that is hidden and packaged inside other software that looks normal and legitimate.
Choices:
a. Worm
b. Virus
c. Spyware
d. Trojan
LLM Explanation: A Trojan, short for Trojan horse, is a type of malicious software that disguises itself as legitimate software. It tricks users into installing it on their systems, and once activated, it can carry out various harmful actions like deleting files, stealing data, or creating backdoors for other malware. Unlike viruses and worms that replicate themselves, Trojans rely on deceiving users to spread.

Question Text: What devices can be used to implement DHCP Snooping? (Choose two answers)
Choices:
a. Hub
b. Layer 2 switches
c. Routers
d. Layer 3 switches
e. Access Points
f. End users
LLM Explanation: DHCP snooping is a security feature that can be implemented on Layer 2 switches and Layer 3 switches. It helps prevent DHCP spoofing attacks by allowing only trusted ports to send DHCP messages and by validating DHCP messages received on untrusted ports. Routers, hubs, access points, and end-user devices cannot implement DHCP snooping.
URLs: ['Cisco Networking Academy: CCNA Routing and Switching', 'Cisco Press: CCNA Security 210-260 Official Cert Guide']

Question Text: Which of the following Cisco Firepower NGIPS’s features provides more insights into and control over the users, applications, devices, threats, and vulnerabilities in your network with real-time visibility?
Choices:
a. Security automation
b. Granular application visibility and control
c. Contextual awareness
d. Superior effectiveness
LLM Explanation: The Cisco Firepower NGIPS feature that provides more insights into and control over users, applications, devices, threats, and vulnerabilities in the network with real-time visibility is granular application visibility and control. This feature enables administrators to gain deep visibility into the applications running on their network, identify and control application usage based on risk, and enforce policies to improve security posture.
URLs: ['Cisco Firepower Next-Generation IPS (NGIPS) Data Sheet: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/security/firepower-ngips/datasheet-c78-736775.html', 'Cisco Firepower NGIPS Overview: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/firepower-ngips/index.html']

Question Text: What can be accomplished with a brute-force attack?
Choices:
a. Guess a user’s password
b. Make a server unavailable
c. Spoof every possible IP address
d. Alter a routing table
LLM Explanation: A brute-force attack is a method of guessing a user's password by systematically trying every possible combination of letters, numbers, and symbols until the correct password is found. It does not directly make a server unavailable (which would be a denial-of-service attack), spoof IP addresses, or alter routing tables.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, Chapter 8: Network Security Concepts', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/what-is-a-brute-force-attack.html']

Question Text: Social engineering attack is accomplished through human interactions. It uses psychological manipulation to trick users into making security mistakes or giving away sensitive information.
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. Social engineering attacks exploit human psychology and interactions to manipulate targets into divulging sensitive information or taking actions that compromise security. Attackers use techniques like phishing emails, impersonation, or creating a false sense of authority to trick victims. The goal is to bypass technical security controls by exploiting the human element, which is often the weakest link in an organization's security.
URLs: ['NIST Special Publication 800-63B Digital Identity Guidelines: Authentication and Lifecycle Management', 'OWASP Top 10 Web Application Security Risks', 'Social Engineering: The Science of Human Hacking by Christopher Hadnagy']

Question Text: Which of the following human security vulnerabilities attacks is a type of attack that targets high-profile employees, such as the CEO or CFO, in order to steal sensitive information from a company?
Choices:
a. Social engineering
b. Phishing
c. Whaling
d. Pharming
LLM Explanation: Whaling is a type of phishing attack that specifically targets high-profile employees, such as CEOs, CFOs, or other executives, in order to steal sensitive information from a company. The attackers often research their targets and craft highly personalized messages to trick the victims into revealing confidential data or transferring money.

Question Text: Which of the following human security vulnerabilities attacks is the attempt to obtain sensitive information such as passwords and credit card details by disguising oneself as a trustworthy entity?
Choices:
a. Social engineering
b. Phishing
c. Whaling
d. Pharming
LLM Explanation: Phishing is a type of social engineering attack where the attacker attempts to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information like passwords or credit card details by disguising themselves as a trustworthy entity, often via email. The attacker may impersonate a legitimate company, bank, or even a colleague to gain the victim's trust. Whaling is a targeted phishing attack aimed at high-profile individuals, while pharming involves redirecting website traffic to a fake site. Social engineering is a broader term that encompasses various psychological manipulation techniques, including phishing.
URLs: ['NIST Special Publication 800-61 Rev. 2: Computer Security Incident Handling Guide. https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-61r2.pdf', 'CISCO: What Is Phishing? https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/email-security/what-is-phishing.html', 'Kaspersky: What is Social Engineering? https://www.kaspersky.com/resource-center/definitions/what-is-social-engineering']

Question Text: Which of the following security features rejects invalid and malicious ARP packets and prevents a class of man-in-the-middle attacks?
Choices:
a. DoS
b. DAI
c. Packet secure
d. ARP protect
LLM Explanation: Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) is a security feature that validates ARP packets in a network and discards ARP packets with invalid IP-to-MAC address bindings. This helps prevent certain man-in-the-middle attacks, such as ARP cache poisoning, by not relaying invalid or malicious ARP replies out to other ports in the same VLAN. DAI relies on the DHCP snooping binding database to verify IP-to-MAC bindings.
URLs: ['Cisco - Configuring Dynamic ARP Inspection (https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst6500/ios/12-2SX/configuration/guide/book/dynarp.html)', 'Cisco Press - CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 15: IP Services']

Question Text: In a reflection attack, the source IP address in the attack packets is spoofed so that it contains the address of the victim.
LLM Explanation: In a reflection attack, the attacker spoofs the source IP address of the packets they send to make it appear as if the packets are coming from the victim's IP address. The responses are then sent back to the victim, overwhelming their system or network. Therefore, the statement is true.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, Chapter 14: Network Security Concepts', 'https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/ddos/glossary/ip-spoofing/', 'https://www.imperva.com/learn/application-security/reflective-amplification-ddos-attack/']

Question Text: Type the command that needs to be configured on a switch to automatically recover from the err-disabled state, when caused by port security.
Choices:
a. recovery cause psecure-violation
b. errdisable recovery psecure-violation
c. errdisable recovery
d. errdisable recovery cause psecure-violation
LLM Explanation: The correct command to automatically recover from the err-disabled state caused by port security violations is 'errdisable recovery cause psecure-violation'. This command enables the switch to automatically re-enable the port after a specified time interval when it has been error-disabled due to a port security violation.
URLs: ['Cisco Networking Academy, CCNA Routing and Switching: Switched Networks, Port Security Configuration', 'Cisco IOS Network Management Command Reference, Release 12.2, errdisable recovery']

Question Text: A next-generation firewall sits at the edge of a company’s connection to the Internet. A network engineer has been configured to prevent Telnet clients residing on the Internet from accessing Telnet servers inside the company. Which of the following might a next-generation firewall use that a traditional firewall would not?
Choices:
a. Match message destination well-known port 23
b. Match message application data
c. Match message IP protocol 23
d. Match message source TCP ports lower than 5400
LLM Explanation: A next-generation firewall can use application layer inspection to identify and control traffic based on the application data, regardless of the port being used. Traditional firewalls typically only match on IP addresses, protocol numbers, and port numbers. While choices a, c, and d represent traditional firewall techniques to block Telnet using its well-known port 23, a next-generation firewall can go further by examining the actual application data to identify Telnet sessions even if non-standard ports are being used.
URLs: ['Cisco Press CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 7: Security Architectures', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/firewalls/what-is-a-next-generation-firewall.html']

Question Text: Your PC connects to a LAN and uses DHCP to lease an IP address for the first time. Of the usual four DHCP messages that flow between the PC (DHCP client) and the DHCP server, which ones do the server send? (Choose two answers)
Choices:
a. Acknowledgment
b. Request
c. Offer
d. Discover
LLM Explanation: In the DHCP process, the server sends two of the four messages: DHCPOFFER and DHCPACK. The DHCPOFFER message is sent by the server in response to the client's DHCPDISCOVER message. It offers an IP address and other configuration parameters to the client. If the client accepts the offer, it sends a DHCPREQUEST message. The server then responds with a DHCPACK (acknowledgment) to confirm the lease and provide the client with the finalized configuration parameters.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 17: Understanding DHCP - by Wendell Odom', 'RFC 2131 - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol - https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2131']
